questions.text: A previously healthy 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of wrist pain. He was playing football when he was tackled from behind and fell forward onto his outstretched right hand with his wrist extended. Examination shows a tender, soft tissue swelling of his right hand; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray series of the right arm is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Galeazzi fracture is an extension fracture of the radial shaft that is usually caused by a fall on an outstretched arm. In contrast to the findings seen here, however, an x-ray would show a fracture of the junction of the distal and middle thirds of the radius shaft with subluxation or dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. Furthermore, Galeazzi fracture typically affects children.
Image Description:

X-ray of the distal lower arm (left, lateral view; right, PA view)

A distal third radius fracture (green outline, bottom left) and distal ulnar head dislocation (green dashed line) can be seen; this fracture pattern is referred to as a Galeazzi fracture. Fracture of the first metacarpal bone (green outline, top right) is also visible.

B) CORRECT:

Colles fracture is an extension fracture of the distal radius that is commonly caused by a fall onto an outstretched hand and manifests with tenderness, soft tissue swelling, and restricted range of motion at the joint, all of which are seen here. Complications of Colles fracture include median nerve injury, compartment syndrome, and malunion or nonunion. Closed reduction may be considered as conservative therapy, but more severe fractures (e.g., unstable, intraarticular, or open fractures) require surgical therapy.

See “Overview of radius and ulna fractures.” table.
Image Description:

X-ray wrist (left: PA view; right: lateral view) after a fall onto an outstretched hand

A metaphyseal fracture of the distal radius (green line) shows dorsal angulation of the distal fragment and impaction. (The vertical white line represents the axis of the radius. The horizontal white line represents the right angle that the radial articular surface physiologically stands at. The dotted white line illustrates the dorsal angulation of the distal fragment.) This type of fracture has been termed a Colles fracture. The pronator quadratus fat pad is displaced and seen as a convex lucency (red curved line). A fracture of the ulnar styloid is also present (white arrow).

C) INCORRECT:

Boxer's fracture is a fracture of the metacarpal neck that typically results from direct trauma to the clenched fist (e.g., from punching), whereas this patient fell on his outstretched hand with the wrist in extension. An x-ray would show a transverse fracture of the 4th or 5th metacarpal neck with volar angulation rather than a fracture of the radius.
Image Description:

X-ray right hand (oblique view)

An acute oblique fracture of the fifth metacarpal neck is accompanied by volar and radial angulation of the distal fragment. Sometimes termed a “boxer's fracture,” this injury is frequently the result of a closed fist colliding with a solid surface at high speeds.

D) INCORRECT:

Monteggia fracture is a fracture of the proximal third of the ulnar shaft associated with the dislocation of the radial head that typically results from a fall onto an outstretched and pronated forearm. On physical examination, Monteggia fracture manifests with pain localized to the elbow joint rather than the wrist. Additionally, and in contrast to the findings seen here, an x-ray would show a fracture of the proximal third of the ulna with anterior dislocation of the radial head. Moreover, Monteggia fracture is more common in children.
Image Description:

X-ray of the elbow (lateral view, positive mode)

Fracture of the proximal ulna with anterior dislocation of the head of the radius.
The radiodensity of soft tissue anterior to the elbow joint is also increased.

E) INCORRECT:

Scaphoid fracture typically results from a fall onto the outstretched hand with the hand in extension. However, an x-ray would show a fracture line through the scaphoid (or no fracture line, as up to 20% of all scaphoid fractures are not seen on initial x-rays) rather than a fracture of the radius.
Image Description:

Radiograph of the right hand: scaphoid fracture (arrow) following a fall on the outstretched hand.
(1 = scaphoid; 2 = lunate; 3 = triquetrum; 4 = pisiform; 5 = trapezium; 6 = trapezoid, 7 = capitate; 8 = hamate; I–V = metacarpals; R = radius; U = ulna)

F) INCORRECT:

Smith fracture is a type of distal radius fracture that typically results from a fall onto the palmar-flexed wrist, whereas this patient fell on his outstretched hand with the wrist in extension. On physical examination, a Smith fracture manifests with a so-called “garden-spade” deformity. An x-ray would show volar displacement of the distal fragment rather than a dorsal displacement.
Image Description:

X-ray wrist (left: lateral view; right: PA view)

A comminuted intraarticular fracture of the distal radius (red overlay) is accompanied by radial displacement (red arrow) and volar angulation (red line and angle) with respect to a line perpendicular (green dashed line) to a line through the shaft (green line). An ulnar styloid fracture (green overlay) is also seen.
questions.hint: The x-rays show a fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal fragment of the radius. This type of fracture is associated with a so-called “dinner-fork” deformity seen on physical examination.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of pain in her left wrist. She was cleaning a table when she slipped forward and fell onto a flexed hand. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and osteoporosis. Current medications include perindopril, pitavastatin, and alendronate. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. Examination shows warmth, tenderness, and edema of the left wrist. Range of motion is decreased due to pain. An x-ray series of the left arm shows multiple fragmentations at the distal radioulnar joint and an intraarticular oblique fracture with volar displacement of the distal fragment of the radius. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Internal fixation with intramedullary nailing is mainly used for long bone diaphyseal fractures (e.g., femoral, humeral, and tibial shaft fractures). This patient, however, has a distal radius fracture. Moreover, her osteoporosis in the setting of a fall has predisposed her to a comminuted fracture, which complicates management and recovery. Intramedullary nailing is unlikely to be sufficiently stable; if surgery is needed, plates are typically used.

B) INCORRECT:

A sling and swathe splint is indicated for the management of shoulder dislocation after reduction of the dislocation. This patient, however, has a distal radius fracture. Moreover, her osteoporosis in the setting of a fall has predisposed her to a comminuted fracture, which complicates management and recovery. Splinting is unlikely to be sufficiently stable.

C) INCORRECT:

Closed reduction with percutaneous pinning (CRPP) is indicated for excessively angulated boxer's fractures and supracondylar humerus fractures. Closed reduction is not the treatment of choice for an intraarticular, comminuted fracture because these fractures are unstable and a closed reduction is likely to be lost. Moreover, this patient's osteoporosis makes her a poor candidate for CRPP, as she has a higher risk of neurovascular, tendon, and pin-related complications.

D) CORRECT:

Open reduction internal fixation (ORIF) and other forms of operative management are indicated for complicated distal radius fractures (i.e., comminuted, intraarticular, severely angulated or foreshortened, or unstable after reduction). Osteoporosis, which this patient has, is a risk factor for both comminuted and distal radius fractures, complicates management and recovery, and is an indication for ORIF. Barring the development of any concerning neurovascular findings (e.g., decreased sensation due to compression of the median nerve, absent radial pulse), uncomplicated distal radius fractures can be managed conservatively.

E) INCORRECT:

A hanging-arm cast is indicated for the management of a humeral shaft fracture and left in place for 1–2 weeks with subsequent imaging and bracing. This patient, however, has a distal radius fracture. Moreover, her osteoporosis in the setting of a fall has predisposed her to a comminuted fracture, which complicates management and recovery. Casting is unlikely to be sufficiently stable.
questions.hint: This patient's x-ray findings of an intraarticular fracture with volar displacement of the distal fragment of the radius indicate a complex fracture.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his father after he fell off his bike. His father reports that his son has been learning to ride his bicycle without training wheels; he lost his balance and fell on his outstretched right hand. He was wearing a helmet and has been reporting severe pain in his right wrist since the accident. He has mild asthma and takes short-acting bronchodilators as needed. He is in the 25th percentile for height and weight. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 96/67 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild swelling and acute tenderness to palpation of the right wrist. Range of motion is limited by pain. The radial pulse is palpable. X-rays of his right wrist are shown; they show a bulge along the dorsal side of the radial and ulnar metaphyses without significant angulation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Smith fractures commonly occur after a fall on the outstretched hand, but they are complete fractures and typically manifest with volar and radial displacement of the distal fragment after forced flexion, while this patient has an incomplete fracture without displacement after falling on an extended hand.
Image Description:

Fracture of the distal radius with volar displacement of the distal radial fragment and dorsal angulation at the fracture site.

B) INCORRECT:

Salter-Harris fractures are complete fractures through the physis and most frequently occur during growth spurts in puberty, with x-ray typically showing physeal widening. This child's age and incomplete fracture with metaphyseal bulging on x-ray indicate a different diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

A torus fracture should be suspected in children who present with pain and swelling of the distal forearm after experiencing an axial force that causes impaction of the distal radius and/or ulna (e.g., fall on an outstretched hand, fall from a height), typically at the junction of the metaphysis and diaphysis where the bone is more porous. The periosteum in growing bones is thicker and stronger than in adults, which is why children are more prone to incomplete fractures (e.g., torus fractures, greenstick fractures). X-rays typically show mild or no angulation at the fracture site, disruption and bulging of the cortex on the side of the compressive force (concave side), and an intact convex side. Treatment consists of immobilization with a splint or a cast for 3–4 weeks.

See “Characteristics of incomplete fractures” table.
Image Description:

In a complete fracture, there is a discontinuity between the bone fragments, whereas in incomplete fractures, the fracture line is either absent or does not completely traverse the entire bone. Incomplete fractures are more common in children due to their thicker, stronger periosteum and the greater elasticity of growing bones. Types of incomplete fractures include:

Buckle (torus) fracture: A compressive force results in bulging, i.e., buckling of the cortex. More specifically, a buckle fracture is characterized by bulging of only one side of the cortex (the concave side), while a fracture in which the bulge is circumferential is referred to more precisely as a “torus fracture.” However, the terms are frequently used interchangeably.

Greenstick fracture: There is discontinuity of the cortex and periosteum on the convex (tension) side of the fracture, but bending occurs only on the concave (compression) side.

Bowing fracture: There is angulation but no discontinuity of the cortex or periosteum.

D) INCORRECT:

Colles fractures commonly occur after a fall on the outstretched hand, but they are complete fractures and typically manifest with dorsal and radial displacement of the distal fragment. This patient, in turn, has an incomplete fracture without displacement.
Image Description:

Fracture of the distal radius with radial and dorsal displacement. Commonly a result of falling onto the extended wrist.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's history of falling on an outstretched hand, wrist pain, swelling, and incomplete fracture pattern are potentially consistent with a greenstick fracture. However, greenstick fractures are the result of an axial force that causes bending of the distal radius or ulna, which is not seen in this patient. X-ray typically shows some angulation and disruption of the cortex and periosteum on the side of tension (convex side) with intact periosteum and cortex on the side of compression.
Image Description:

X-ray distal left forearm (left: lateral view; right: PA view) of an adolescent

A greenstick fracture of the distal radius is seen. The cortex on the radial (lateral) side of the fracture is disrupted and buckled (green overlay). However, the fracture line has not traversed the bone. The ulnar (medial) side of the radius is bowed, but the cortex is intact (black dotted line).

Greenstick fractures are incomplete fractures. Typical locations are the shafts of the bones of the forearm and lower leg.

Red overlay: growth plate
questions.hint: This type of incomplete fracture is common in children and manifests with bulging or buckling along the metaphysis.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after he lost control of his bicycle, tumbled over the handlebars, and landed on his outstretched arms. His immediately felt pain in his left wrist, but no deformity was evident. Movement of his left hand and wrist causes pain, but he reports no numbness.
On examination, the dorsal/radial aspect of his distal forearm is swollen and tender; there is no palpable deformity. Abrasions are evident on the palm, but he has no ecchymosis or open skin near the area of the swelling and pain. He holds his wrist in flexion, and extending his wrist is painful. He has intact sensation to light touch in his hands, and capillary refill in his fingers is less than 2 seconds.
Radiographs reveal a compression fracture of the dorsal cortex of the distal radial metaphysis. The volar cortex remains intact.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Recommend closed reduction followed by application of a long-arm cast
Recommend open reduction internal fixation followed by application of a short-arm cast
Apply a sling and recommend rest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The fracture is nondisplaced, so no reduction is needed.

B) INCORRECT:

The fracture is nondisplaced, so no reduction is needed.

C) CORRECT:

Buckle fractures (also called torus fractures) commonly occur at the distal metaphysis of the radius and ulna in children. The mechanism is often an axial load with the wrist in extension, such as a fall on an outstretched hand. A buckle fracture is a nondisplaced fracture that involves only one cortex, typically the dorsal cortex. Historically, these fractures have been treated with a short-arm cast. However, recent studies have shown similar fracture healing and better function with use of a removable short-arm splint compared to a cast.

Key learning point: Buckle (torus) forearm fractures in children should be managed with a short-arm removable splint for 2 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

Adequate healing is easily achieved with a short-arm splint or cast, so the additional immobilization at the elbow with a long-arm cast is unnecessary.

E) INCORRECT:

A sling can be used for comfort to support the forearm, but it does not immobilize the wrist and should not be used as solo treatment for buckle fractures of the distal forearm.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents for evaluation in the emergency department 2 hours after injuring his left wrist during a backward fall from a skateboard onto a concrete surface. He landed on his outstretched hand with his wrist extended. He was wearing protective equipment, including a helmet. He denies head trauma, loss of consciousness, and other injuries.
His vital signs are within normal limits. He is visibly uncomfortable and holding his left arm in a splinted position. The radial aspect of his distal left wrist is edematous and very tender to palpation. The skin is intact. His wrist’s range of motion is limited because of pain. However, he has full pain-free range of motion of the elbow. The distal neurovascular status of his left upper extremity is intact.
A radiograph of the left wrist is obtained (figure). The angulation is measured at 15 degrees.
In addition to analgesia, which one of the following approaches is most appropriate for immediate management in this case?

choices.text: Hematoma block, closed reduction, and application of a splint
Hematoma block and application of a cast
Application of a splint and follow-up in 2 weeks
Closed reduction and application of a sling

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Angulation of a fracture can be assessed on radiographs by comparing the direction of the distal bone fragment in relation to the direction of the proximal bone. In this radiograph, a distal radius metaphyseal fracture with around 15 degrees of dorsal angulation can be seen.

A healthy adolescent with an angulated/displaced distal radius fracture needs to have the fracture promptly reduced. A closed reduction should be performed to provide appropriate alignment. Referral to orthopedics would be indicated for health care practitioners who are uncomfortable or inexperienced with reductions. Adequate analgesia is paramount for reduction of a fracture. An initial oral medication, including acetaminophen, another nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug, or an opioid analgesic, is appropriate. A hematoma block can be performed by injecting a local anesthetic, usually lidocaine, directly into the fracture site; this limits discomfort and reduces resistance to the reduction. Aspiration of perifracture hematoma blood before injection indicates correct placement. After the closed reduction is achieved, a short-arm plaster splint should be applied to stabilize the reduction and maintain adequate bony alignment. Postreduction radiographs are advisable, to confirm success of the closed reduction and acceptable bony alignment. Last, the patient needs outpatient follow-up to assess his progress and apply a cast.

Prompt orthopedic consultation is appropriate for open fractures, intra-articular fractures, significant physeal injuries (usually Salter-Harris grade III or above), unstable fractures, or failed closed reduction — or if the provider is not comfortable with reduction of fractures.

Key learning point: In addition to analgesia, a hematoma block, and closed reduction, the most appropriate initial management for an isolated distal radius metaphyseal fracture with 15 degrees of dorsal angulation is application of a splint.

B) INCORRECT:

Application of a cast without reduction may lead to a need for further manipulation at a later time.

C) INCORRECT:

Following reduction, application of a sling alone is inadequate because of the risk for reduction failure. A sling may be applied in concert with the splint if the patient wants it for comfort.

Application of a sling without reduction is inadequate for a patient with a radius fracture.

D) INCORRECT:

Application of a splint would be acceptable initial management, but referral for reduction should be expeditious (within 3 days, not 2 weeks).

E) INCORRECT:

Following reduction, application of a sling alone is inadequate because of the risk for reduction failure. A sling may be applied in concert with the splint if the patient wants it for comfort.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presents to an urgent care clinic for wrist pain after falling while snowboarding earlier in the day. His father was ahead of him on the slope and did not witness the fall. The patient says he did not lose consciousness or hit his head, and he was wearing a helmet.
On examination, there is focal tenderness over the distal radius, swelling, and moderate pain when wrist range of motion is assessed. Radiographs are obtained (figure).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Skeletal survey and consultation with child protective services
Short arm cast, with repeat radiographs in 2 weeks
Removable Velcro splint for 2 to 3 weeks and avoidance of contact sports for 6 to 8 weeks
Rest, ice, and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications, with follow-up in 2 days if no improvement

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Obtaining a skeletal survey and contacting child protective services is warranted when nonaccidental trauma is suspected. However, distal radius buckle fractures are common pediatric injuries, and this patient’s history is consistent with his presentation. Fractures that are more concerning for nonaccidental injury include rib, skull, scapular, and sternal fractures.

B) INCORRECT:

A short arm cast is indicated only when there is radiographic evidence of cortical breach or if reduction is necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Manual reduction is not indicated unless the degree of angulation is >10 degrees; in these cases, the arm should be casted after the reduction to provide stability during healing.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has a distal radius buckle fracture with characteristic bulging of the cortex of the distal radial metaphysis, as evident on wrist radiographs. Buckle, or torus, fractures are the most common wrist fractures in the pediatric population. The injury is commonly sustained when a person falls onto an outstretched hand with the wrist in extension. The flexible, immature bone and thick periosteal covering allow the force to be absorbed, leading to a cortical “buckle” without cortical breach. (The alternative name, “torus fracture,” describes the resemblance of this outcropping to a head-on view of bull horns.) Pain is typically the only presenting symptom. Physical examination may reveal edema, ecchymosis, and bony tenderness. Two-view, plain-film radiographs are important to assess for deformity and cortical breach.

Traditional management of distal radius buckle fractures has involved circumferential casting and immobilization. However, in a systematic review of 24 studies, immobilization in a removable Velcro splint for 2 to 3 weeks resulted in easier use of the limb, better physical function, and less difficulty with daily activities than casting or more-substantial splinting. In addition, use of the Velcro splint was less expensive and more convenient without a significant increase in pain or fracture complications.

This patient should be counseled about appropriate immobilization and the avoidance of contact sports and dangerous activities for 6 to 8 weeks. With these interventions in place, follow-up and repeat imaging are unnecessary unless concerns about pain or function persist.

Key learning point: Appropriate management of a nondisplaced distal radius fracture in a pediatric patient includes a removable Velcro splint for 2 to 3 weeks and no contact sports for 6 to 8 weeks.

E) INCORRECT:

Although a nondisplaced distal radius buckle fracture is considered to be inherently stable, some form of immobilization and support is indicated to protect against further injury. The combination of rest, ice, and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medication alone is therefore not adequate.

Moreover, Monteggia fracture is more common in children.

E) INCORRECT:

Scaphoid fracture typically results from a fall onto the outstretched hand with the hand in extension. However, an x-ray would show a fracture line through the scaphoid (or no fracture line, as up to 20% of all scaphoid fractures are not seen on initial x-rays) rather than a fracture of the radius.
questions.hint: The x-rays show a fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal fragment of the radius. This type of fracture is associated with a so-called “dinner-fork” deformity seen on physical examination.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with wrist pain after a fall. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness over the distal radius. X-rays show a distal radius fracture with 15° dorsal angulation, 2 mm radial shortening, and no intra-articular involvement. Neurovascular examination is normal. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Closed reduction and sugar tong splinting with orthopedic follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate orthopedic surgery consultation is not required for this stable fracture. The angulation is less than 20°, and there is minimal shortening and no neurovascular compromise or intra-articular involvement.

B) INCORRECT:

A volar splint provides inadequate immobilization for a distal radius fracture. A sugar tong splint is the appropriate initial immobilization method because it provides better stability and prevents forearm rotation.

C) INCORRECT:

Cast application without reduction would leave the fracture in an unacceptable position. The dorsal angulation requires reduction to restore normal anatomical alignment before immobilization.

D) INCORRECT:

A CT scan is not routinely indicated for simple extra-articular distal radius fractures. X-rays provide sufficient information for diagnosis and initial management of most distal radius fractures.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This fracture meets criteria for nonoperative management with closed reduction and sugar tong splinting, followed by orthopedic referral. The 15° dorsal angulation and 2 mm shortening are within acceptable limits for closed reduction, and the fracture is extra-articular and stable.
